We are meeting here at a very timely moment, following Eurostat's notification of the 2016 deficit figure at the beginning of the week, which validates what the Commission has been saying for several months, that is to say that the he Greek economy has shown itself to be resilient in the face of the turbulence of 2015 and the effects of capital controls. According to the program definition, the 2016 primary balance should amount to 4.2% of GDP. It should be remembered that Greece is doing significantly better than the 0.5% of GDP target set by the program, nine times better all the same. Still, of course, subject to confirmation. Certain elements are the subject of ongoing discussions with the Greek authorities and Athens, but the performance is still to be welcomed. Greece is therefore on track to meet its target of 1.75% in 2017 and 3.5% of GDP in 2018. This is what the Commission thinks. These developments are the result of Budget consolidation package which included quality parametric measures, adopted in 2015 and 2016, with a cumulative budgetary return. We must still be aware of the effort figure of 4.5% of GDP. Such efforts should not be forgotten or ignored. They must be grounded and deepened. This is good news, but we must be careful not to be complacent about the economic and social situation in Greece. As I told you the last time I was with you, the positive trends seen in 2016 now seem to be stalling, in particular due to the delays in the culture of the second MES program review and we know that unemployment remains at unacceptable levels in absolute terms, especially youth unemployment. Investment must also be boosted further to support growth. Greece cannot afford to lose the momentum gained in 2016. This requires constructive support from all to accompany the process of anchoring reforms and the recovery, which has started to emerge. For me and for the Commission, this means that the Greek authorities, all the institutions, all the players must be even more vigilant. We must work constructively and collectively to bring the second review to a close as quickly as possible. Where are we? What are the next steps? I am just repeating what the president of the Eurogroup said. First, substantive agreement was reached in Valletta this month on the post-program budgetary parameters needed to secure the deal. This should also help to close the review and fill in any remaining gaps. The post-program package for 2019 and 2020 will be fiscally neutral if forecasts are correct. It will consist of new budgetary measures amounting to 2% of GDP. But these measures basically amount to a restructuring of public finances to strengthen growth and social protection. Indeed, the package also includes 2% of pro-growth measures to be implemented if Greece meets its primary surplus targets, as we believe it will. At the same time, the Commission will continue to closely monitor the social impact of the package, in particular on pensions. The Valletta accord and the contacts that have been made since have enabled the institutions to return to Athens this week. The goal is shared, and that is to reach a technical agreement quickly. This deal is essential to mitigate the risks posed by delays, including over the positive budgetary result recorded in Greece last year and to deal with uncertainty, which is the Greek economy's worst enemy. Greece and its authorities have made significant progress on areas of the agenda that remained unfinished. I will not go into detail here since they were presented during our discussion at the last plenary session. But the current mission should make it possible to make progress on the elements that remain to be dealt with, both as regards the conditionality of the review and the post-program measures. We remain convinced that, thanks to the fundamental reforms and the efforts to be pursued within the framework of this program, the Greek economy is able to turn the page on a long and difficult period, but it must be supported, and not hindered by uncertainty. The recovery must also be sustained and anchored. In the work of the Eurogroup, under the responsibility of its President, the Commission is doing everything in its power in its role as facilitator to ensure that the balanced package of measures is implemented faithfully and swiftly. Once the technical agreement has been obtained, the Greek authorities must implement a series of measures prerequisites. I note that some have already been implemented, but others need to be finalized in the days and weeks to come legally and administratively. It’s not an easy task, but we are convinced that we can do it. If all goes in a constructive way, the evaluation of this second review should allow a formal agreement - this is what I hope for at the next Eurogroup - and thus pave the way for the disbursement of funds. Finally, the Commission will also continue to support efforts to make Greece's debt more sustainable. We believe it is necessary and possible. As you know, we have been arguing for some time that a more realistic path for the primary surplus will be needed after the program ends. This is what we are fighting for. Without a more credible trajectory, markets will be unwilling to lend at reasonable rates and Greece will continue to depend excessively on the support of its European partners. Ultimately, it is a matter of burden sharing between Greece and the Eurogroup. In this context, the Commission is obviously ready to work to find a fair compromise. I believe very sincerely that this is what we are succeeding in doing with Jeroen Dijsselbloem.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before we begin the debate, I inform you that I will not be accepting a "blue card" question today.We are in a hurry because the vote will last about an hour and a half.So we have to hurry.Thank you for respecting the speaking times during the debate.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, first of all, I am of course going to address the President of the Eurogroup and tell him that I regret, like many of my colleagues, the comments he may have made recently on the Southern countries, because the social distress experienced by many of our fellow citizens deserves better than caricatures and that seemed to me to be an insult to all those who work in those countries. Let's talk about Greece, where precisely this social distress is felt much stronger than anywhere else. Almost half of young people under 25 are unemployed, nearly half a generation is sacrificed, thousands of people are genuinely suffering and the health care system is in trouble. We must all make the effort to understand. Of course, to understand does not mean to apologize and, the commissioner has told us, we must not be complacent. If Greece is in this situation today, it must be remembered that it is in large part because of some of its leaders, such as Mr. Tsipras who, due to his unwillingness to make reforms, beginning of its seizure of power, brought us into this populist impasse. Today, we finally see that there is a commitment to reforms. The situation is slowly improving. We need to achieve lasting improvement, and of course we hope that the second tranche of aid can be released before the summer. The difficulties, which we also encounter with the IMF, are perhaps an opportunity to re-examine the question of Europe's independence in terms of macroeconomic surveillance and lending of last resort. We cannot continue to embrace the IMF's moods. To this end, I firmly believe in developing the European Stability Mechanism towards a genuine European Monetary Fund. I think, for Greece, for the euro zone, for the rest of Europe, this is an issue of the future.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I am glad to hear that Mr Dijsselbloem recognises that his words were inappropriate and says that they were misunderstood.  But now let us focus on Greece: the Greek economy is at a turning point. The primary surplus for 2016 has reached an astonishing level – far above the target of 0.5. IMF forecasts have proved to be wrong. Notwithstanding such an impressive fiscal consolidation, economic recovery is underway. The agreement reached at the last Eurogroup on the fiscal structural measures and the contingent expansionary package has been difficult, but now it gives us the concrete hope that this top—level agreement can be reached quickly, possibly in a few days. On this basis, we expect – and urge – the next Eurogroup to conclude the second review and to address the necessary debt relief issues. It is evident, as you said, that the primary surplus of 3.5 can be sustainable only for a very limited period of time. We need a medium—term fiscal path which is economically realistic and credible and a package of medium-term debt relief measures that is consistent with such a revised path. This overall political agreement is urgent and essential, not only for allowing Greece to honour its financial commitment in good time, but is necessary to keep up the positive momentum of the economy and to allow Greece to return to bond markets and to be included in the ECB QE programme, which will be a powerful driver towards stability, confidence and growth. Greek citizens deserve this. Europe deserves this. Let us not waste this opportunity; let us not miss the deadline again. Let us honour our duty and obligation of unity and solidarity and restore credibility and hope in the European project.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, Mr Dijsselbloem, the Greek people are sending you a message of indignation and protest over your shameful and unacceptable statements. We were not convinced by the explanations you gave us, because you told us something else when the matter was raised in the Finance Committee. The Greek people are also sending you a message of protest against the unacceptable policies of the Eurogroup, which have turned Greece into a vast social graveyard. With the memoranda, Mr Dijsselbloem, instead of reducing public debt, it skyrocketed; poverty reached 40% of the Greek population, the unemployed reached 1.5 million, Greece lost 25% of GDP, small and medium-sized enterprises disbanded , pensions have been reduced by 50%, wages have been slashed, public property is being sold instead of a lentil plate to foreign lenders, and yet all this is not enough for you. Impose in good cooperation with the government and a fourth memorandum, which reduces pensions, reduces tax-free, seizes PPC public property. You impose primary surpluses, ie installments for amortization of 3.5% for many years, and all this without even giving money, without settling the debt. What will happen, Mr Dijsselbloem, to the remaining € 19.5 billion in the third loan package? What will happen to the money you have to return, the profits of the European Central Bank from the Greek bonds? You give less loan capital. So reduce the measures by 25%. Also, the government, instead of reducing pensions, must distribute as a social dividend what is due due to the over-coverage of the primary surplus. Mr Dijsselbloem, the Greek people will soon send you the message, because there is another way.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, I will start with some remarks in English due to Mr Dijsselbloem's presence and then I will continue in my barbaric Swedish. In this House, we usually use quite colorful language and as soon as anybody else uses some colorful language then all hell breaks loose. I, as a journalist and as an avid debater, have used words far worse than Mr Dijsselbloem. I think we should have some sense of humor when we reach out to each other. Even if you probably will not be very pleased by this exculpation, then I have a great understanding that we, under stress, and with a great heart, discuss things which are hard to discuss. Our most fundamental challenge concerns not only Greece but almost all countries. In the coming weeks, that challenge will apply to e.g. France to the highest degree. All our member states are today torn by a discussion in which, on the one hand, they put forward amendments that are not really amendments but which are ultimately just a way of trying to put the blame for their own sins - sins that have nothing to do with women or alcohol - other. This is the discussion we are having in all countries, and it is life-threatening. In the current situation and in the situation that will arise, which has already arisen in Greece and which will arise within a few weeks in France, we have a time frame to solve these problems. We can roughly determine that time frame. We must be able to build confidence in this system in the months and years leading up to the 2019 parliamentary elections. If we fail to do so, we will face huge challenges. If France does not succeed in solving its problems, then we know that on the other side of the political spectrum there will be ruthless work to undermine all realistic attempts to solve the problems. We saw the same thing in Greece. While I was involved in the troika report, we encountered this reluctance to look realistically at our challenges.As long as we do not look at our challenges realistically, we will not be able to solve them either.We have a huge understanding of the people of Greece.As a poet and journalist, my father was a great friend of that people and wrote a book about that people.So we have a big heart for Greece, but we should have an equally big heart for those who are trying to come up with the realistic solutions.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Mr Dijsselbloem and Mr Moscovici, there is no other time to lose. The Eurogroup has until 22 May to plan future debt and primary surplus measures. It is President Junker, not me, who belong to the European People's Party, Mrs Grossetête. Greece has made a huge effort and must be recognized in practice. Junker says the same. The primary surplus for 2016 closed nine times above the agreed target, forty-two times above the eternally failed forecasts of the International Monetary Fund. The numbers say it and you, Mr Dijsselbloem, and you, Mr Moscovici, admit it. So the International Monetary Fund and European institutions must finally bridge their differences over debt and surpluses, so that on 22 May we have an agreement. Dobrovskis, who also belongs to the European People's Party, says so. The Greek people have paid a lot, they have made huge changes all these years, with unemployment, with cuts, with sacrifices. It now reaches the backs of the Greek people between Berlin and the International Monetary Fund with this ping pong! Mr Dijsselbloem, how do you, a Social Democrat, want to go down in history? As the president of the Eurogroup who contributed on the initiative, under pressure, to have a comprehensive package deal on 22 May or for your unfortunate statements about women and drinks? You have time to think about it and act accordingly.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Dijsselbloem, and I am happy he finally made it to our plenary. Welcome. Today we talk about Greece once again, and once again we talk about budget cuts. The Eurogroup that you chair, Mr Dijsselbloem, is insisting on yet another round of cuts: of cuts to pensions, and of taxing people who have as little as EUR 500 a month in their pocket. These measures will continue to suffocate the recovery in Greece and will also increase social disruption, but nevertheless the Greek government is actually doing what you wanted it to do. It is delivering all those things; it does its ‘homework’, as you like to call it, despite the most horrific social cuts. It is time to acknowledge that, and it is time to give Greece some time to breathe and to actually do the long-term reforms that we really need and that are really necessary.  But we also shouldn’t forget the other side: it’s also the Eurogroup that must deliver. It’s actually you, Mr Dijsselbloem, who has to do his homework. Where is the debt relief that was already agreed for Greece in May 2016? Where is the end of the austerity paradigm that has brought so much suffering and very little success? What have you done as Chair of the Eurogroup, together with your fellow finance ministers, to end tax avoidance and tax evasions? By letting big companies avoid taxes, we lose EUR 70 billion euros each year, and that’s roughly half of the EU’s annual budget – money that we very much need to invest into Europe’s future. We cannot be tough when it comes to cuts for poorer people and be lenient when it comes to the tax avoidance of big companies. Frankly, I think the Europeans deserve a change of that policy. Let me also say something a little more personal, because I actually don’t believe that this was colourful language which you have used, Mr Dijsselbloem. It is nice that you say you did not want to insult southern countries. Very nice, but you still don’t understand that with your statement you have insulted half of the European Union population – all the women in this House, all the women everywhere in the European Union – because you say that women are an object that you either buy or spend money on. This is unacceptable, and I don’t understand how you cannot even see that there is a problem. This has brought about a lot of problems – a loss of credibility to the European Institutions, to us, to the Commission, to you and to the Council, and this is now your legacy that you have to deal with. I find this unacceptable. Shame on you, Mr Dijsselbloem, for disrespecting half of Europe’s population.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank President Dijsselbloem for coming here, in this Parliament, to give an account of what his words have been, because we consider it scandalous that a finance minister of a country like Holland, who fact is a tax haven and which has been adopting a surplus of more than 6% for several years, like Germany, is giving moral lessons to the countries of the South, saying that we spend money on alcohol and women. In this I would like to know if we calculated what is the difference in competitiveness that has been created by the country Holland, or by Germany for the surplus and by Holland on the issue of tax evasion, or maybe even from Luxembourg, we see that there would be a lot of money to be given to the countries of the South that are undergoing the policies linked to the stability of the single currency and the Euro. Greece is continuing to make unsustainable sacrifices in the conflict of interest on which this European Union is founded, because the European Union is founded on a conflict of interest between the market and politics. We sell off ports and airports, we sell off all public assets and the welfare of Southern Europe. In exchange for what? In exchange for nothing, because the interest on these loans is unsustainable. So let us realize what you are pursuing as a policy, because the peoples will judge you and continue to judge you and the European Union, founded on conflict of interest, will not move forward in this way.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are talking about Greece, but in reality we are talking about the whole Eurozone and this project. President Dijsselbloem - I would do better to say outgoing president and outgoing minister -, you demonstrate and have demonstrated with your work all that is criminal and destructive in the Eurozone project and in the Maastricht project. Greece, as an old pro-European and Italian Prime Minister once said, is exactly the manifestation and example of the greatest success of the Euro, because the real goal of the Euro is not and never will be the convergence of countries and the well-being of citizens, but it is only the squeezing of workers' rights and wages and the destruction of countries, as happened in Greece. The policies that you have carried out in this country are showing that the unsustainability of this project and the dissolution of this project are only a matter of time. These are just issues that are brought forward, but which at some point will present their bill. You have wrought with your policies the destruction of the working class, the destruction of the peoples, not only of Southern Europe but also of countries like yours, and the electoral results have demonstrated this, with a drastic drop in socialists not only in Holland but in many European countries. What will happen now? His parable and the parable of the socialists throughout Europe show how this project is inevitably and inexorably destined for dissolution. Today you can also rejoice in the victories of Pyrrhus, such as that of Prime Minister Rutte or that of Macron's banking and finance spokesman in France, but your policies will inexorably lead to the destruction of a project that is imperialist and colonialist, as it is today. demonstrated with the results of the third adjustment program - as you call it - for Greece. History and citizens are already there presenting the bill and it is only a matter of time before this project comes to an end and finally the peoples and nations of Europe will be able to return to hope for a prosperous future without the Euro and without the European Union.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Mr President, after seven consecutive years of economic bloodshed by the Greeks and the implementation of a premeditated genocide against them with the implementation of the measures of the memoranda, what rational person still believes in the hilarious tragedy of the constant revisions of the economic adjustment program for Greece? The real goal of the international usurers is to impoverish the Greeks financially, to force them to tolerate their governments handing over to these usurers the subsoil and submarine space of our country rich in energy resources and precious metals. So the problem of Greece is not economic. It is political and will be resolved in a political way. Greek nationalists will not tolerate what is happening in our country what is happening in Venezuela. We do not tolerate the transfer of our national sovereignty and the transformation of our country into a third world one in order to save the euro and to enable the political and economic elites of Germany to dominate in Europe. Finally, I point out that we do not tolerate any Mr. Dijsselbloem to devalue and ridicule the Greek nation, which gave humanity culture. He has neither the moral nor the political stature to do that. I therefore demand that he apologize to the Greek people for what he has said unacceptably against him.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: - Mister President! Mr Dijsselbloem, nice to have you with us this morning and respect for your statement. But I would like to return to the substantive debate in which you here in this House definitely have supporters for your course and the course of the Eurogroup. My group, the EPP, is once again very concerned about current developments in Greece. The Greek government is playing with fire once again and is betting on last-minute concessions. I would like to make the following clear: Debates about further debt relief are not only impossible under contract law, these debates will not solve the root of the problem: A focus on debt relief alone is misleading. Argentina has gone into state bankruptcy with around 60% debt. Japan is still in the markets with a debt burden of around 250%. A fundamental reform of the economy, the labor markets and the pension system and measures for more competitiveness and effective privatization are what is and remains essential for the future. We need an honest change in action in Greece. However, if the International Monetary Fund's allegations are correct, namely that the surplus figures may have been embellished, I still don't see this change in action. These are not a good prerequisite for successfully completing the overdue review. I therefore appeal to you to complete the review as quickly and appropriately as possible, applying the applicable law precisely.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Eurogroup, thank you for your words of appeasement. Especially since, when we have heard from my predecessor in this debate, I believe that your role in concluding this second review of the third plan is absolutely essential. We count on you to maintain a reasonable balance between those who always want more demands and those who talk about excessive concessions. There is a kind of negotiation strategy here which puts Greece in the position of the prisoner's dilemma from which you must help us get out. From this point of view, time is against us. We have a chance to get out of this trap, this prisoner's dilemma: it is the Eurogroup of May 22. Your responsibility in coming here, finally, to this European Parliament is to come to this conclusion, because what is at work today is devastating, as we know very well. Not for the euro zone but first for the Greek economy which we claim to get back on track. When we see that 14 points of GDP were lost between 2009 and 2016, that the primary balance has moved by 17 points over the same period and that nothing has yet been done on the substantial relief of the Greek debt, we see well where is the problem. Finally, I would like to say that no one will be surprised that by pursuing this strategy, the unsustainable Greek debt continues to increase. Mr President of the Eurogroup, thank you for being with us today, but we are counting on your full commitment so that the Eurogroup of May 22 will allow this review to be concluded.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: - Mr President, I have three points and a question. First, the growth of the Greek primary surplus is unlikely to last very long. According to the International Monetary Fund, it was due to one-off factors such as higher tax revenue. In the longer term, according to well-known professors Panizza and Eichengreen, it is unrealistic to expect sufficient surpluses to service Greek debt. Secondly, as German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schäuble has pointed out, the Treaty of Lisbon prohibits the reduction of the nominal debt of a member of the euro area, and debt is not even Greece's biggest problem, but competitiveness. Third, instead of restoring competitiveness, economic adjustment programs have exacerbated the problems of poverty, generating opportunities lost for generations, although there has always been a quicker and less painful way to restore external competitiveness, namely the abandonment of the euro. Does money have more value to us than freedom, equality, fraternity, the well-being of Europeans or other great European values? Is it not time to recognize the euro for what it really is, the instrument of exchange?

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: - Mister President! Mr Dijsselbloem, it's great that you do us the honor. We missed you something. I don't want to say too much here about the situation in Greece, the essentials are known. With Japan and Argentina, Mr Balz himself gave an example of why it is completely crazy to concentrate solely on reducing national debt by cutting government spending. Your recent economic analyzes were very impressive - attributing the problems of southern Europe to too much alcohol and women! Because my colleague Nils Torvalds asked for a bit of humor - if something like that qualifies you to head the Eurogroup, please tell me where you can apply for the job. So I don't want to talk around the bush. The Dutch sent you off with about 5%, and the policy of cuts was also a program to destroy social democracy in Europe - see France, for example. But you did not mention that the euro bailout was also a bailout for Northern European banks, not to mention the Dutch tax tricks of corporations that finance ministers like you use to grab Europeans' wallets. The euro zone needs public investment and democratic control of the euro group. You justified your attacks against southern Europe with Calvinism. That's why I have Christian advice for you: go, go with God, man!

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: - Mr. president. Mr Dijsselbloem, look, don't cheat us. In your original German you speak of "northern countries" and "countries in crisis." You are pointing south when you make your statements in the original German; And therefore, look, I tell you one thing: anyone can have a bad day, nothing happens. But you had it very easy. You apologized and the matter settled. But I do not know if it is because of his arrogance, or, worse still, because of political calculation, that he has not wanted to do so. And you are unable, after having said that and not apologizing, to continue as president of the Eurogroup. But look, it's not what interests me the most today. What interests me most is the situation in Greece, because the worst thing is that you as president of the Eurogroup have not been able to manage this either. Where is the debt renegotiation? We would have expected you to have helped and to stand next to the European Commission, when it has tried to defend European law in Greece against attack by others and you have not wanted to do so. Nor has he wanted to defend a rational fiscal path. And, look, there is only one conclusion: due to your lack of respect for the countries of the south and your terrible performance as president of the Eurogroup, you only have to resign.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Mr President, there is a scene in the British sitcom, Fawlty Towers, in which Basil Fawlty is thrown into an illogical rage by his car breaking down yet again. He begins to whip it with a tree branch while swearing at it. Jeroen Dijsselbloem has surely become the Basil Fawlty of Europe. Instead of just admitting that the euro does not work and the engine is broken, he rains down abuse on the unfortunate people of southern Europe in an impotent display of ill temper.  We are nearly a decade on from the start of the crisis and yet we are still talking about keeping Greece locked in a currency union with Germany. This is unbelievable. The engine is faulty, the vehicle does not drive and all the state of denial is achieving is more human misery, more poverty, more unemployment, more damage to the social fabric and more deflation without end. A proud nation is being sacrificed to the ideology of integration at all costs and, from where I am sitting, that looks shameful.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: - A warm welcome to Minister Dijsselbloem.I'm going to try, as a populist, to be the only one to stick to speaking time today.Mr Dijsselbloem's predecessor, Jan Kees de Jager, said on September 15, 2011 that all the tax money that went to Greece will be returned with interest.These statements now seem somewhat surreal, because even with an artificial injection of 80 billion a month, there seems to be no improvement in Greece.One day the creativity of Goldman Sachs bankers will also come to an end.Mr President, according to the rules of ministerial responsibility, Mr Dijsselbloem will therefore have to account for the sustainability of the promise of his predecessor and that is why I now ask him, Mr Dijsselbloem, straight to the point: will the Dutch taxpayer get his money, thatwent to Greece, back with interest?

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). - Mr President, the fact that Mr Dijsselbloem, who a few weeks ago made provocative statements to the people, today praises the SYRIZA-ANEL government for its anti-labor reforms proves that the SYRIZA-ANEL government, the European Union and the The International Monetary Fund, all together, is sitting at the same table imposing new harsh measures on workers. To the already very heavy backs of the people, the SYRIZA-ANEL government adds new unbearable burdens with further reduction of pensions, tax-free, labor jungle, with facilitation of collective redundancies, complete abolition of the Sunday holiday, delivery of energy filters to companies, airports, ports. This will be the updated anti-workers memorandum, the necessary condition of the bloody surpluses for capitalist development, which the people will pay to feed the sacred cow of the profitability of capital and its goals, for investment, for access to markets, of debt, which are foreign and against the popular interests. The so-called countermeasures, which the workers will again pay for, concern new privileges in the monopolies and meals for the impoverished victims of the anti-popular policy. Workers to respond to Labor Day and the general strike thereafter.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: PPE). - Mr President, the economic and social costs of managing the Greek crisis are growing as the second evaluation of the Third Program, which was originally scheduled for February 2016, is delayed. The delay maintains a climate of insecurity. I characteristically mention that the 40 billion euros that left the banks' deposits during the crisis of 2015 have not been returned to the banks, as the savers have not yet been convinced of the prospects of the Greek economy. In addition, a large percentage of small and micro-enterprises avoid transactions through the banking system, because they have not settled all kinds of debts created due to the crisis and are afraid that their income will be frozen and thus they will not be able to continue operating. The real economy therefore needs a real agreement for the second evaluation, which will give real solutions to the big problems.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: - Mister President! Commissioner Moscovici, I have listened to you, Mr President of the Eurogroup, Mr Dijsselbloem, I have listened to you. And if I am to believe what you two say - and I do - then the problem of the second review is actually solved. But I ask myself: why are so many days, so many weeks and so many months actually being wasted in order to bring about a real improvement in the interests of the country? That is why, Mr Dijsselbloem, we invited you to come to this House in December. We have the impression that games are being played in the euro group - games that have nothing to do with Greece, games that have nothing to do with the euro zone and not with the economy in the European Union, but much more often with any Elections in other Member States and maintaining the prevailing view that the Greeks are a people who allegedly do not want reforms and allegedly do not want to work effectively. I tell you, Mr Dijsselbloem: the Eurogroup has a problem because it speaks with split tongues. How can it be that you say: you have done your homework and the German finance minister declares in public that the Greeks have not even completed half of the reform requirements? This duplicity is one of the reasons trust in the euro area is waning. This duplicity is one of the reasons people are also becoming increasingly anti-European, and it is your job to make sure the Eurogroup is telling the truth and properly helping to solve problems. What you really lack is effective democratic control, parliamentary control. We very much agree with you that we need an ESM that takes on the role of an economic fund. We very much agree that the Commission you have to have the say, but you need parliamentary accompaniment so that your language becomes clear.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: - Mister President! I agree with Mr. Bullmann. What we heard here today was again a fairy tale hour. Greece is on a difficult path. But it's moving forward, it's getting better, and tomorrow it will be even better. The IMF also accuses the Commission and those responsible for making super-optimistic forecasts. I had it checked. Not a single growth forecast that the Commission has made in the last ten years has been correct. What are you doing? They pray for health according to the Coué method: I'm fine, I'll be even better tomorrow and even better the day after tomorrow. This leads to nothing. The IMF said: It is precisely this health prayer that makes the problems in Greece worse because it does not allow them to sustain debt. And then you stand up and say: Success is the primary surplus. Every financial scientist knows that this can be manipulated. What you are doing with it is: You are wasting the future potential of the economy because there are no more investments, because no more bills are paid, and you are still proud of that. The IMF went on to say that it had once put the exit from the euro on the discussion agenda, but none of those responsible had wanted to know about it. What kind of policy is that? Politics means: close your eyes and go through. Surely that cannot be help for Europe and the euro zone. You really have to know what the problems are. And what needs to be done for Greece? It's simple - everyone knows when they think about it. The triad: exit from the euro, profits and economic recovery, debt repayment and start-up financing. It is necessary. But is this Parliament discussing it? Is Parliament a Control? No, this is not a Parliament that is taking control of the Commission. It doesn't matter to get a misguided currency construction. It depends for that To care for people in Europe.That is our task!

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, Mr Dijsselbloem, in 2013, when the Eurogroup under your presidency had decided to cut Cypriot deposits, sowing uncertainty about deposit security throughout Europe, I asked you there at the Eurogroup: "Are you incompetent or do you serve other goals? " Now, looking at the situation of the Greek economy, the answer I give is: You are executing financial death contracts. Together with the willing Greek memorandum governments, you have imposed economic strangulation and impoverishment on workers and retirees. You are shaping a working middle age with high unemployment. The hopes of the Greek new generation have turned into a nightmare. In the name of debt and reconstruction, you have turned Greece into a protectorate of creditors, with the consequence that they are looting public property. But, Mr Dijsselbloem, Mr Moscovici, we now know: The reorganization of the Greek economy, the equitable development of Greek society and economy is out of the deadly embrace of the memoranda and the Eurogroup, out of the nightmarish eurozone and in rupture with the neoliberal anti-democratic Join.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: - Madam President! Mr Moscovici, I would like to address you directly. The most recent changes to the memorandum on taxes and pensions will, in turn, unilaterally unload necessary reforms at the weakest. That means, in turn, people with lower pensions as well as those with low incomes will be burdened by further reform measures. You have promised to subject each memorandum to a social impact study. Are you going to deliver this now, or are you shirking that commitment? And to you, Mr Dijsselbloem, I would just like to say one thing. Basically you have said frankly here: The ESM should be expanded intergovernmentally and the Commission should please stay out of this area. That means the weakening of European democracy. Mr Bullmann mentioned it. We need European institutions of the Eurogroup under full democratic control - including the European Parliament. If you say that the Commission should stay out of it, you're saying nothing else than: The European Parliament should stay out of it too. That is not how I imagine a President of the Eurogroup with democratic responsibility!

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, finally the President of the Eurogroup deserves us for his presence in the Chamber, but his statements come too late, a delay which is a sign of rudeness and little attention to the role he plays. We all know that the task of the Eurogroup is to discuss issues related to the accountability and growth of the Eurozone, but we also know that the Eurogroup has good times and bad weather in matters of fiscal, monetary and structural policies. Ask the Greeks. The population is poor and the people have no work. And rest assured, the Greeks did not spend their savings on women and alcohol, but they pay the price of the troika. The Greek tragedy ended with the German "all-in" who, like a skilled gambler, took possession of Greek state assets such as ports and airports at bargain prices. The Eurogroup certainly does not do the good of the citizens. Dare to admit the truth and stop making fun of millions of unwitting victims.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Madam President, Greece is bankrupt and for a long time. The Eurogroup granted it a third aid plan in 2015, amounting to 86 billion euros. In return, he demanded even more austerity, even though the misery there is already intolerable. The state has had to organize the distribution of soup kitchens for those who have nothing left, and infant mortality is on the rise. The Eurogroup also demanded additional privatizations to fuel a fund intended to recapitalize the banks. We think we are dreaming. The truth is that the Union is largely responsible for the Greek bankruptcy. It should never have integrated Greece into the euro zone, because the euro is too strong a currency for it. The only solution to save Greece is to write off part of its debt and let it resume its national currency to revive its economy and especially its tourism. But this the Union will never admit, because it has neither the lucidity nor the heart to resolve it.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: - I would like to thank the president of the Eurogroup for being here on King's Day, a national holiday in the Netherlands. In response to the words of the president of the Eurogroup in the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, let me borrow the wise words of our queen: "That was a bit stupid." Very stupid in fact. But I appreciate your statement and I think it is important that we move over that and focus on Greece. Because that is what we have to talk about now: Greece where things seem to be going a bit better but where a hosanna mood is not on the agenda. It is not yet clear whether the improvements mentioned are structural. Not all agreements in the Memorandum of Understanding have yet been fulfilled and a number of important reforms, especially the improvement of competitiveness, are still pending. What is now needed - I agree with both gentlemen on the part of the Commission and of the Eurogroup - is that we work seriously, that no more time is wasted and that the conditions are met, so that the the next installment can actually be paid out quickly to Greece. What is not needed, and I say to Mr Gualtieri and to the Socialist Group, is that we are now prematurely starting a discussion about expanding the ECB buy-back program to Greece, a country that is still waiting for billion tranches from the aid program. This buy-back program is not relevant for this. If Greece is no longer in the excessive deficit procedure, which country will be? So first things first and get to work seriously.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: S & amp; D). - Madam President, Commissioners, seven years ago it became clear that insurance in Greece is not sustainable due to the huge deficits. The troika's response was "Cut pensions, increase contributions and taxes." Sounds reasonable and probably a twelve year old would accept that too. Seven years later, with formal unemployment skyrocketing to 24% and 34% of people living below the poverty line, we are discussing for the fifteenth time measures to cut pensions and increase contributions and taxes. But the child we mentioned earlier has gone to university and at least he has learned that work is what supports security and that only job growth ensures a sustainable system. Greece needs three reforms: a public administration that slows down any business endeavors, a tax system for development and a mechanism to fight corruption. The Greek governments do not do that, because they love the client state. But how long will you be satisfied with accounting games? Growth and only growth should be your goal.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - Welcome to King's Day, Mr Dijsselbloem. Statements about booze and women are always unwise and because your apologies have been delayed for so long, the matter went on unnecessarily long, unfortunately. Content-wise, the Eurogroup's policy towards Greece is anti-social. Anyone who has ever driven the road from the airport to Syntagma Square knows that too. 60% of all retail and business premises are vacant. They are bankrupt, the people who worked there. What do you see? Small and medium-sized businesses in Greece have been wiped out. The engine of the economy no longer exists. Many Greeks are unemployed and people who can do it leave the country. And then don't come up with that nonsense smoke curtain that Greece has had a budget surplus for so many years. More countries in Europe have a large debt, such as Greece. The financial and economic situation of a country is determined by completely different factors. Then what? I already gave you a report in 2013: Greece out of the Eurozone, partially discharging its debts and Greece remaining a member of the EU and retaining the right to the funds. If not, the judgment of history will be harsh.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, we are discussing again today the Greek fiscal adjustment program and the second assessment, which calls for a savage surplus of 3.5%, which requires China to grow, cuts, further reduce pensions, further reduce the welfare state, privatize, forced expropriations of public wealth and natural resources, at a time when 36% of Greeks are below the poverty line and youth unemployment is above 50%, and as a culmination provocative contempt for every concept of democracy and constitutional institutions by pre-legislation, colleagues, measures by the Greek Parliament. This is what we are presented to Parliament, the supreme democratic institution of the European Union, the gentleman who considers half of Europeans lazy, drunk, women, as the president of an informal extra-institutional body. I wonder, is this the quality of the institutions and the vision for the future that we propose to the Greek people but also to the other peoples of Europe? I am sure, Madam President, that Mrs Le Pen can thank us for the full support that these policies offer her in her election campaign.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: - Madam President, Mr President of the Eurogroup, Mr Moscovici, dear Mr President of the Eurogroup, I have to tell you eye to eye that if no one was able to do so at the meeting of the Eurogroup, I here in the European Parliament will tell you, man the face and eye to eye, that we are not satisfied with a simple apology. The President of the Eurogroup is unable to continue as President of the Eurogroup because, after making the statements he has made, he shows that he has a prejudice. How can you be talking about Greece here, when you have a prejudice against the Greek people, the Cypriot people, the Portuguese people, who made the greatest sacrifices and who did it with governments, curiously from the EPP, when it was the socialist governments , from his political family, who destroyed our public accounts and who put countries like Greece, Cyprus and Portugal into bankruptcy, forced to make a very demanding program? Do you think that people who made immense sacrifices, who had to give up their wages, their pensions, are people who spend money on glasses and women? Is that your design? How does someone with this mentality have the authority and legitimacy to come and implement programs and provide solutions for Greece, as is the case today, or for Portugal, or for Cyprus, or for other countries? Mr Dijsselbloem, here, in an instance that represents the European peoples, I tell you there is only one way out: it is to resign and resign as soon as possible.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S & amp; D). - Madam President, Mr Moscovici, Mr Dijsselbloem, my country is approaching a decade of crisis and a vicious cycle of austerity. I wonder if you can enlighten us if someone is ultimately to blame for giving us a fictitious picture of a final solution every time, thanks to your successful program, while this convenient government continues to vote on whatever it is asked to stay in power. At the same time, the South spends not only night but also day unimaginable amounts of equipment and border guards for the European Union, while companies from major European Union countries buy our trains, our airports, land and Greek property at a bargain price. At the same time we see surpluses in Greece. But I wonder why we are asking for new measures. Don't you think they can be maintained? Are they artificial? Can you tell us who will eventually take responsibility? You, the IMF, Seibel or just a willing government? because otherwise we know who will pay the bill. Major reforms and burdensome measures have been voted for the next government, while confidence across Europe, given the election results, seems to have been lost and Euroscepticism on the rise.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: - Madam President! Mr. Dijsselbloem! Yesterday, Prime Minister Orbán pointed out that just 10 years ago the economy of non-euro area Hungary was at roughly the same level as that of Greece. Today Hungary is in a much better position than Greece - higher growth, lower unemployment and, above all, lower new borrowing. And that, Mr Dijsselbloem, does not only apply to Hungary, it also applies to all non-euro countries in the European Union. Have you ever wondered why? These countries have remained responsible for themselves. Because of the euro, institutions in Greece such as the IMF, the Commission, the ECB, Merkel and Schäuble have taken on responsibility. And not only that: now the responsibility for national debts, bank debts and of course also for unemployment insurance should be communitized everywhere in the euro zone. Instead of just giving Hungary advice, we should also learn something from Hungary, and that means: if we are all responsible for everything, nobody will be responsible anymore.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: PPE). - Madam President, for Greece we must make the crisis an opportunity, to positively surprise the Greek people, our partners, the markets. The Prime Minister to convene a council of political leaders. Greece needs a national consensus, a national strategy; to show the care of a good and prudent family head. Greece needs giant public and private investments, now that delusions and leftist ideologies are gone, now that the models are not Venezuela, Chávez, the leftist dictator Maduro. Now that the primary surplus is not accounting for the disaster. Now that the primary surplus is not the destruction of households, the fainting of children from starvation, the icy nights and the hungry days of retirees, as Mr Tsipras told us. Now is the time to get through this great crisis at the lowest possible cost.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Madam President, and I am glad that today Mr Dijsselbloem shows regrets. I think apologies are called for, even though I do not doubt for any moment his good intentions. There is much more today than unfortunate communication. The 3.5% surplus target is unrealistic for a longer period: that is one of the reasons that the IMF has consistently argued that, without debt relief, the Greek economy will be in the woods for many years – even decades to come.  Moreover, I find the contingency measures on the table disturbing and dangerous. It entails the importation of a pro-cyclical policy of engineering a downturn.  So let’s be honest; let’s not play games. What Greece needs is debt relief in combination with reforms and investments. Only then will Greece become independent and be able to build a better future for itself. So let us be sensitive but also honest in our communication.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). - Madam President, Mr Dijsselbloem's position is a highly political position and I will fully agree with my dear Portuguese colleague, Mr Rangel, that after his insulting, unacceptable and disparaging statements and statements about the countries of the South, female, the least he should have done was to have already submitted his resignation. And for those who do not know history, I want to tell him and emphasize that without the countries of the South, the European Union would be very different, not to say that there would be no European Union, because, if he knew the history of the European Union, he would knew very well that the countries of the South, which despised, from 1973 to 1995, that difficult time for Europe, where there was the Iron Curtain, the Eastern Bloc, only three countries joined the European Economic Community to support Europe : Greece, Portugal and Spain. The Greek people are proud, Mr Dijsselbloem, as are the peoples of the South, and I must point out to you that I, as a Cypriot, will never forget the harsh and unjust measures you have taken for my country, and I will not particularly remind you that Mr Junker said that if he had been in your position, he would never have made the decision you made for Cyprus. But you have done the same for the other countries of the South and your statements come to confirm that they were indeed not accidental, they were statements of prejudice, and one cannot remain in this position of the Eurogroup today with this mentality and this perception. Your presence in the Eurogroup has not benefited either the Eurogroup or the euro area or the countries of the South. We are proud of our origin and our origin from the South, but in no case are we proud of your presence and your place in the Eurogroup.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: - Madam President, Mr Dijsselbloem, let it be clear that the explanations that you came to give to this Parliament about your unacceptable statements about the countries of the South arrive late, do not erase the seriousness of your insults and give you neither credibility nor political conditions forextend his term as president of the Eurogroup.As for Greece, this delay in completing the program evaluation is intolerable, when the results achieved by the Greek government and people are evident and when the European Commission comes here to praise the progress made.The truth is that Greece is the victim of positions more interested in Germany's elections than in defending the eurozone.It is urgent to end this, stop playing with fire and finally close this program, do justice to Greece and the Greek people.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). - Madam President, Mr Dijsselbloem, I honestly say that I would expect you to have the courage to confess before us that what you have said about the people of the South, and especially about women, is simply unacceptable and I am sorry that you are not doing it and I hope you do. , while you are still president of the Eurogroup. In essence now, you create an image of the Greek economy based on the photo of the moment and avoid putting your finger on the type of nails, which is none other than the structural changes and the course of their implementation. The reality is completely different: Half of the young Greeks are unemployed, 35.7% of Greeks are faced with the spectrum of social exclusion, the health system is collapsing, pension and tax-free cuts are coming and the primary surplus of 2016 seems to be it is not sustainable, because it is based on disposable measures. The completion of the second evaluation obviously does not offer any guarantee for the prospect of completion of the program in the summer of 2018, while your commitment to settle the costs of the Greek debt is pending from November 2012. Greece needs another policy with a reduction tax cuts, which will be implemented by a government committed to reforms. But most of all, you, Mr Dijsselbloem, and you, Mr Moscovici, share the responsibility to have full access to the markets in August 2018. We will all be here and it seems that then no one will be able to rely on a magic image.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: - Madam President, Mr Dijsselbloem, we appreciate the opening statements that attempted to explain your statements in the interview in the German newspaper. We appreciate them, but it is true that we cannot fail to recognize that many of us in this House are deeply disappointed, not only by the literalness of the words, but also because it affected that division between North and South, between creditor countries and debtor countries, which we need to rebuild in Europe. Many of us are working, and I know that all of us in this House want to rebuild those bonds of cohesion between the countries of the European Union. And the Commission and Commissioner Moscovici are doing a great job to rebuild and redirect economic policy with greater flexibility, with more space for fiscal policies. We are negotiating that third package with Greece, and we need to apply that philosophy of flexibility in the approach to Greece. And therefore, later than soon the conditions of the debt will have to be reviewed.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: - Madam president. Mr Dijsselbloem, thank you for appearing in this House after his last unfortunate visit and his even more unfortunate absence at the last sitting. His explanations come late — very late — and bad — very bad. Today he tells us: "It's not what I said." He lies, and you know it. Yes it is what he said: he said what he said, and what he said is unacceptable and definitely disqualifies him for the presidency of the Eurogroup. Let's talk about Greece. The priority of the Greek Government and the objective of the European Union must be for the Greek economy to regain lost competitiveness, and through this to grow and create jobs. I say publicly that I recommend Greece to follow the example of Spain. That after tough reforms and the efforts of citizens, it has managed to regain the path of growth and job creation. Spain is growing by more than 3%, and in the last year it has created more than half a million jobs. It is true that Spain does not have, like Greece, a populist government. She has a popular government and that is a big difference. Mr Dijsselbloem, you will now have a new turn to speak. She has a new chance, surely the last. Take advantage of it: apologize and announce her resignation.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: - Shall we start with the good news?And that is that the political agreement at the beginning of April averted further escalation of the Greek crisis, and I think that is good.The only question is at what price.The question is whether the agreements on important topics such as poverty reduction or better medical assistance for Greek elderly will actually become reality, because it seems as if social protection is not high on the priority list.Now we know since yesterday, the day of the presentation of the European social pillar, that social standards are also European standards.One of those standards is that the social partners can decide themselves at what level they want to conduct collective bargaining.And my question is: can we now make sure that those social norms are non-negotiable, not now, not on May 22, and not later?

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - I too share the disappointment of many colleagues who have expressed their statements, Mr President, and we must all be careful in our work not to divide people, not to divide Europe into first-class and second-class.I support the solidarity that Europe shows with Greece, because I think we are in a time when solidarity will have to come first among us if we want to live in a common European Union.On the other hand, of course, we also expect the necessary reforms that each country must make in order to improve its economic picture, to ensure growth, to also provide new jobs.Reforms are needed in a wide variety of areas.It is not always just saving that often, it is often necessary to change education systems, change business environments and also bring new business models to countries.And focus on that.And this is a way out of the crisis for the Greeks.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the right-wing leaders of the European Union have promoted dangerous austerity policies in Europe, especially in Greece. These policies have been self-defeating and they threaten to tear Europe apart, as they have now torn the UK away from Europe. Austerity has fed the cause of the rise of the far—right, divisive nationalism and dangerous xenophobia. These forces exploit the concerns that ordinary citizens have regarding economic policies that harm them, and so they resort to scapegoating others. But let me remind you what the European treaties say: Article 3 of the Treaty on the European Union says that the EU shall work for a social market economy and social progress, and promote social justice and solidarity among States. That is the spirit of the true European Union, and I believe that social justice in the UK and Europe is still possible, and we must choose it together.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, Mr Dijsselbloem, your slanderous statements about drinks and women demonstrate the racist prejudice you face against the peoples of southern Europe by portraying them as supposedly prodigal. This prejudice makes you unsuitable for the position of President of the Eurogroup, who must be President for all the Member States of the Eurozone and not just for the so-called virtuous North. However, if you are indifferent to the outcry and refuse to resign, you should at least show practical remorse, immediately promoting the completion of the second evaluation of the Greek program. You must respect the enormous sacrifices of the Greek people and proceed to the concretization of the measures for the relief of the Greek public debt. Stop hypocrisy at last and give Greece a real opportunity.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). - Madam President, Mr Dijsselbloem, you have once again imposed measures that impoverish Greeks with pension cuts and barbaric taxation. Of course you are continuing the same failed recipe for the supposed rescue of Greece, but as it has been proven so far, you have only saved the funds and the bankers. Of course you had willing collaborators in the sale and mortgage of the national wealth of Greece to the memorandum governments that deceived the Greek people and put the country under a commission. Normally you should apologize to the European Parliament for the failure of your programs, which instead of growth brought recession, led the Greek citizens to poverty, while together with the government today you follow the same wrong political recipe. But we assure you that, when the Greek people choose to have a national government that will not betray their trust, you and all the representatives of the institutions, as we say in Greece, will take a step back. As for the famous statements about women and alcohol, they characterize you only.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE). - Madam President, Mr Dijsselbloem, you have insulted my country, you have insulted European women, I would wait for you to recall, because, as you know, your statements were not misinterpreted; they were simply made public. I will counter it, to express to you the following concern, which concerns the citizens of my country - I also address the Commissioner, Mr. Moscovici: Since you both admit that the country has a surplus and you assume that this surplus will last for the next years, then give an explanation why you impose measures that impoverish the society and the Greek people, measures such as reduction of pensions and tax-free, measures that do not have a developmental character, and why you finally do not contribute to debt settlement, a promise you made to my country since November 2012.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, President of the Eurogroup, I will not link to your statements, there has been a lot of talk. But I am interested in how you will make that connection between responsibility and solidarity, have you stated that you want to make that connection, and how will you improve the experience gained from the crisis? You were talking about a European stability mechanism. How do you apply it as a prevention mechanism? Let's not forget that we are not just talking about Greece. If you have a failure in Greece, it will be a sign that it is not possible for all countries. I don't suspect you of lack of intelligence, but this is about good faith, because the one who made the atomic bomb, blew it up, was intelligent. It's about character and good intelligence. I want you to answer us very clearly how you will make this adjustment for Greece, so that we do not have other countries in the situation of Greece? And don't forget that we're talking about people's lives here, not the papers you make there.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Madam President, Mr President of the Eurogroup, if there was an ounce of respect from the institutions of the European Union for the people of the countries that you offended, and for European women, and you would no longer occupy that place. Showing him the front door, as voters in his country did, would be, to go no further, an act of elementary common sense and civility. But the fact that he still sits there says a lot about the miserable state that all this has reached. Worse than their deplorable statements is what they translate into a reality, that of the euro zone, in which countries and entire peoples are subjected to permanent relations of domination and subjugation that constrain and impede their sovereign development. The lackey's relentless availability to please the chief becomes ridiculous and despicable. But just that, the real problem is much bigger than that. Mr. Dijsselbloem, although he still occupies that chair, make no mistake, what he represents has no future.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Madam President, I do not deserve to mention the name of the Mr Eurogroup and I wanted to tell him that like today, April 27, 1941, the Germans of the Third Reich invaded Greece. An occupation of three years prevailed. A hero, Koukidis, was found, who will not be like him in the country of the gentleman, who, wrapped in the Greek flag, fell from the rock of the Acropolis. Self-sacrifice! This is what the Greek souls show today. They are patient, because the occupation imposed by Germany, the IMF and the master, is in its seventh year and there is no end to suicides, absolute poverty and the sale of Greek property. At some point the Greek will raise his head and say to him: "Get out of here, sir, and you owe us and we owe you nothing."

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S & amp; D). - Madam President, the elections in the Netherlands are over. The first round of the French elections is over. What is the next political stop we have to go through to tell us the truth? What happens with the implementation of the Greek program? Will we need to discuss the second evaluation for the fourth time? Why are we late? What are the specific problems? Clearly, say today, to end with the editing of both Brussels and Maximos, who see everything very nicely, very well in Greece, but things go against the interests of our people and every day the sacrifices of the latter are wasted six years old.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Mr President of the Eurogroup, thank you on behalf of the Commission for your interventions and observations. The state of play of Greece's stability support program is a very important debate and, as you have all pointed out, it comes at a rather critical time, because Greece is at a crossroads today. After a year and a half of support programs from the European Stability Mechanism, it is now time to consolidate the progress made so far in Greece, to support the economic recovery that started to emerge in 2016, which awaits the conclusion of the review, and therefore ensure a successful exit from the program in 2018, as planned. The Commission once again welcomes the agreement reached within the Eurogroup on 7 April in Malta. I think this should allow the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to join the program. The post-program package - I say it again here - will be budgetary neutral if our forecasts are correct and I say to those who have criticized them here that, in general, in terms of budget surpluses, they have not not deceived. As for growth, that is another matter, because growth is very much dependent on precisely the progress of the program and that is what we have to take into account. All this essentially amounts to a restructuring of public finances to strengthen growth and social protection. There is, it is true, some work to be done in the days to come. (The President interrupted the speaker to demand silence in the hemicycle) However, I am convinced that the current mission can allow substantial progress. We are not very far from the end goal. Therefore, rapid progress must now be made to complete the review of the second program. It requires achieving to an agreement at the technical level in the coming days. For this, I repeat, the Greek authorities will have to implement a series of preliminary measures for the whole program. An agreement on the completion of the second review, which should also provide certainty on the primary surplus and the sustainability of Greece's debt, should be quickly reached between the partners. I am convinced that a lasting recovery, that economic and financial stability are not only in the interest of Greece and its citizens, but very clearly, it is in the interest of all, of the European Union as a whole, and we are aware that we are extremely awaited at this precise moment. We must all live up to the deadline with no short phrases, no ideological position but with a shared concern that Greece will move forward, regain growth and stability, create jobs and can simply move towards exit from the program. It is the Commission's absolute determination to contribute to this.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: President of the Eurogroup. – Madam President, first of all, many Members of Parliament have been very critical about my remarks in the interviews, and of course I fully accept that. The choice of words was unfortunate and people have been offended, and I regret that. The underlying debate still remains valid: that to build a community requires everyone to take responsibility, respecting agreements and frameworks, and, on that basis, moving forward together and strengthening solidarity in the Union and in the eurozone. That is the legacy that I would like to leave. That is what I have worked for and I think, looking back on the last four and a half years, the eurozone is in a much better state than when I came to the job as we are moving out of the crisis and many Member States are back into strong growth. I stress again that my remarks were about the responsibility for all Member States, not some of them, and if the impression was that it was about some of them, I regret that. It was not my intention. I believe that all of us should take that responsibility. I will make one remark about my personal opinions on the development of the European Stability Mechanism (ESM): I believe it can play a stronger role, which would also allow the IMF not to be part of future programmes. I am not excluding them from being part of future programmes and I certainly hope we won’t need any future programmes, but I feel that the ESM can play a leading role and that it should develop in that direction. That does not mean that I wish to take away responsibilities from the Commission. I made my remark about the Commission to underline that I feel that the Commission should stay in the lead as the guardian of the pact and the rules that we share.  Finally, on Greece, Parliament has my personal strong commitment that we will achieve that deal for Greece in May. It needs to be done in May. We have put in a lot of effort. The situation in Greece is not good enough; growth is falling back again where we need trust and growth to continue. So, yes, you have my personal commitment and I will come back to Parliament as soon as possible with that fair deal for Greece. I believe that, already in the package we are discussing now, the emphasis is not on austerity; it is about deep reforms that are necessary to create more growth, and any fiscal outcome of that can be reinvested in Greece and used for the positive policy initiatives so badly needed in Greece.  Finally, yes, we will discuss debt, and debt relief will be needed to find that solution. That is my opinion, and I believe that is shared in the Eurogroup. Last year we already gave that commitment to come back to the issue of sustainability of debt for Greece, because that is the only way that they will come back onto a sustainable path and a sustainable economic future.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The votes will take place in a little while.I will suspend the meeting for a few moments.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written. - The discussions between the European Commission, the European Central Bank, the International Monetary Fund, the European Stability Mechanism and the Greek government will continue. The IMF continues to push for a haircut for Greece, while European creditors expect a primary surplus of 3.5% from next year and thus take Athens' debt sustainability as a given. In the context of the implementation of the reforms promised as part of the third aid package, a haircut, as the IMF is calling for, is politically not feasible at the level of the EU member states in the 2017 election year. The Greeks have long been granted an indirect haircut through interest rate cuts and term extensions. The economic outlook for the current year is good, but Athens lacks the liquidity to make the next multi-billion dollar repayment tranche in July. The progress report of the IMF's European Director, based on data that has not yet been fully evaluated, appears counterproductive in this context, as it made a pessimistic assessment of the implementation of structural reforms and generally of the future of Greece. What Greece needs is a future-oriented approach, a liberation in the form of a comprehensive economic and stability program that creates growth and employment, offers incentives for investment and strengthens the purchasing power of the population. Only in this way can the Greek economy become competitive again and jobs can be created.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: signed up.- Greece is once again on the brink of collapse with its external debt due in July 2017, in the absence of an agreement with the International Monetary Fund, the European Financial Stability Facility and the European Commission.This situation has been repeated insistently in recent years.The reason is very clear: creditors do not want to take their share of responsibility for allowing Greece's external debt to reach unusual proportions (currently 180 percent of Greece's gross domestic product).In fact, a fundamental condition for any restructuring of a country's external debt is not met: achieving a new balance between the country's real revenue-generating potential (after the adoption of reforms) and the debt due in the coming years.In the case of Greece, the need to write off part of the debt is obvious.Creditors oppose it, but in the end they will have to accept this truth.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - Today, there is no respect from the European Union and its institutions for the peoples and especially for women in the countries that the President of the Eurogroup has offended. Today, his resignation is a moral obligation and his failure to do so demonstrates the degree of decay that the European institutions have reached. But the fact that the president of the Eurogroup is still sitting there is still symbolic of the miserable state that all this has reached. Worse than their deplorable statements, is what they translate into a reality, that of the Eurozone, in which countries and entire peoples are permanently subjected to relations of dominance and subjugation, which constrain and impede their sovereign development. The lackey's relentless availability to please the chief becomes negligible and ridiculous. But the real problem is much bigger than that. This is another sign that shows the evidence of the historical limits of this model of integration that is condemned to be dismantled by the peoples in struggle.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I refer to article 22, paragraph 4, of the regulation and I turn to you, as our representative in international relations, to denounce a dramatic case of violation of human rights, the case of Christian Provvisionato, a Italian citizen locked up in a barracks for almost two years, innocent victim of a scandal concerning the trade in a spy software system and therefore detained in the Mauritanian barracks without being charged with any crime. A seriously ill man with diabetes who was debilitated to lose thirty pounds. A man who has now lost hope and who will start an indefinite hunger strike from 1 May that could even put his life at risk. President, Christian is an Italian citizen, but he is also a European citizen, and therefore we ask for the support and action of the Presidency, the High Representative and all the Member States, because we believe that Christian must return home as soon as possible. loved ones and his partner whom he had and must marry. We ask free Christian.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Castaldo, you know that this is not an item on the agenda, but of course we will pass on your observation and your request.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Mr President, to answer numerous calls to the governments of Member States to create more gender equality in European institutions, out of all 28 Democratic states the one we did not suspect, Hungary and Mr Orbán, finally made a move. Ms Gáll-Pelcz is nominated, and she is definitely the best candidate we can get from Fidesz.  Hence, I would like to advise the Members of Parliament to be cautiously supportive and give her the benefit of the doubt. She will prove it right with her future work in Luxembourg.  However, there is another side of the coin, which means that Madame Gáll—Pelcz leaves to Luxembourg and creates a vacancy in the Bureau of our Parliament. This vacation is not predestined to be filled by a member from Fidesz, nor from Hungary, and not even from the EPP Group. By acclamation. Au contraire, Article 20 of the Rules of Procedure stipulates clearly that we must have elections, not a cosy backroom deal. But if we are very much in love with our habitual practices of power sharing, my legal advice will be just a point: by acclamation, the Member who took part in our January elections and with the support of one—third of his parliament is first in line. Only modesty prevents me from calling his name.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr. President, you said it takes a long time.Therefore, I believe that it is not necessary to read the title of the reports.We have all of these elements before our eyes.It is therefore sufficient to mention the name of the rapporteur.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thanks for your advice.Instead, on the budget discharge we have an obligation to mention what we are voting for.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
