text: Member of the Commission, in writing. Commission statement As regards the sharing of information with the European Parliament and the Council in Article 9, the Commission notes that rules on access by the European Parliament to information held by the Commission are already defined in the Framework Agreement agreed by the European Parliament and the Commission. The Commission will therefore apply Article 9 in a way that is consistent with the Framework Agreement and without prejudice to any future general rules on access by the European Parliament and the Council to information held by the Commission.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, it is perfectly within your rights under the Rules of Procedure to take a block vote on all these amendments.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: That is precisely why, Mr.I have already told you that the text will be voted on article by article as it arrived in the Chamber. Precisely because I have the right.(The President reminded the Hon. Preda to behave worthy of the Chamber)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: This concludes the voting round.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - The EIB's financial assets in 2015 show an increase in risk appetite and a push towards special financial instruments. The result is now evident: European resources are increasingly feeding high-risk financial instruments, with an engineering that risks soon leading to the explosion of a new gigantic speculative bubble. In addition to denouncing the huge share of loans granted by the EIB to a country outside the Union and which clearly violates human rights, such as Turkey, I want to point out here that the EIB supports indirect financing operations in favor of small and medium-sized enterprises that they are often hinged on speculative investment funds and do not pursue the objective of consolidating the real economy. In general, then, the EIB is involved in supporting infrastructure projects with a serious environmental impact, with an extremely low response in terms of employment and with little added value from an economic and social point of view. As a result of these considerations, my vote was negative.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of this report, but I also had the remarks I made during the debate.First of all, I believe that the EIB is an important player in our development strategy, for the development of the European Union as a whole, and we need a better focus of funds.The EIB must take the risk of financing those areas where we need infrastructure, we need the support of SMEs on real projects, on job development.The EIB is not like any other bank that runs on minimal risk.I therefore believe that in the next period the EIB needs to be subject to scrutiny and reporting in Parliament in order to be able to truly support the development of areas and increase social cohesion, increase infrastructure, improve infrastructure and connectivity and makejobs in Europe to increase.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur. I believe that the EIB can be the main instrument to fill the current investment gap within the European Union. Therefore I support the call for a more active policy from the EIB, especially to support strategic investment for growth, jobs and innovation. I also believe that it is necessary to strengthen its policy in the field of climate change action to achieve the EU commitments taken within COP 21.  Nevertheless, I would like to underline that there is also a need for increased parliamentary oversight of the EIB’s activities, taking into consideration the lack of transparency, particularly in the selection of projects and the low number of projects in Central and Eastern Europe. Therefore I agree that an interinstitutional agreement between Parliament and the EIB could improve this aspect. Additionally, the EIB should improve its policy to fight against tax avoidance and tax evasion by applying all the EU rules on activities through a swift implementation of the relevant EU legislation and standards.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report, given its essential evaluation of the European Union’s policy objectives in this area. In particular, I welcome the report’s recognition of the principles of economic recovery, the promotion of youth employment, the fostering of innovation and SMEs in the sphere of entrepreneurship, and environmental sustainability and climate action. Notably, I also welcome the report’s recommendation for the monitoring of EFSI’s added value and additionality, thus fostering the geographical spread of the programme as we move forward. There can be no doubt that the sum total of these efforts may result in greater economic and social cohesion across Member States, and I am very pleased that tomorrow in my own constituency, in the city of Limerick, I am hosting an information day for businesses, local authorities, agencies etc. on EFSI and the EIB, which recently opened an office in my own country in Dublin.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Today I voted in favor of the annual report on the control of the financial activities of the EIB for 2015. The strengthening of the economic role of the EIB and the increase of its investment capacity must be accompanied by greater transparency in order to ensure real control public of its activities and project selection. Information on financing opportunities and the consultancy service offered is also to be improved, in order to increase the financing of projects by local authorities and SMEs, as well as to simplify access to its financing. Supporting economic recovery, sustainable growth and strengthening cohesion is a key objective of European policies. Structural challenges, in particular those related to the reindustrialisation of Europe and the digital economy, need to be better addressed to create new economic opportunities, promote the development of a circular economy and improve the use of renewable energy, in line with the objectives policies for the environment, climate and energy.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I would like to begin by saying that I supported this report. It is important to say that the European Investment Bank's statements do show an increase in risk. Generally speaking, an investment bank should take a degree of risk, and it has rules and criteria for making decisions. However, I would like to talk about the fact that the famous Juncker Investment Fund was to be taken as a complement to the activities of the European Investment Bank. Unfortunately, this does not happen very well. We would just need Junck's investment fund to focus more on risky financial instruments and not to compete too much with the European Union's structural and investment funds. This, I think, is a fundamental problem, where a fluctuation then follows, for example, in the activity of the European Investment Bank, which then directs those funds elsewhere. So this should be coordinated at the level of all European Investment Bank and Structural Funds policies.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, what is the purpose of a bank that is backed by the taxpayer and that intervenes in the private sector? The only possible justification is that governments know better than the market. If there is a good bet, investors will see that and will put their money in accordingly, but the notional justification for this kind of bank is that we know better than the market and will make better decisions. As a matter of fact, as we have heard during this debate, that has not been the outcome of these EIB loans, and in fact it never is. If you take that argument to the extreme, you get East Germany rather than West Germany, and North Korea rather than South Korea. We have tested to its limits the idea that the State knows better than the market. The real purpose of a bank like this is that it opens the door for us to promote projects that we happen to like. It therefore inevitably opens the door to favouritism and cronyism. Yet the only solution we have heard today – the only criticism – of all the failings of the EIB is to bring it under more direct political control. In fact, we politicians should learn to do less.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: - The so-called structural reforms have actually been counter-reforms in recent years that have taken away rights and conquests from European citizens.History has taught nothing and now there is a new program to implement, to help theoretically, but in reality to guide states to adopt what was the Greek solution, which so tragically failed in that country and which is wantedextend.This program is a kind of assistance to the suicide of both individual states and the idea of Europe and therefore we are definitely against it.A minimal objective that we tried to achieve with a large majority in the Committee on Culture was to at least remove the field of education from these draconian cures, totally useless to restore the budgets of the States, and even in this we have not been listened to.There is nothing positive to preserve about these failures.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Madam President, I supported the proposal for a regulation establishing a program to support structural reforms for the period 2017-2020. Many Member States face the challenge of weak economic growth after experiencing a severe crisis. That is why structural reforms are key to stimulating growth and supporting the cohesion process. Not only is the design of legislation important, but also its effective implementation. At the same time, I firmly hold the view that the budget provided for the program must not set precedents for the European Commission's funding of future cohesion policy initiatives. In addition, I believe that it should be subject to annual monitoring in view of its effectiveness. In conclusion, I would like to add that the program must also be open to regional and local authorities, especially since the recommendations of the European Semester are sometimes aimed directly at them.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President!The Structural Reform Support Program for 2017-2020 is an important element in supporting and enhancing the development of Member States.It is part of the EU system of economic policy coordination.It is true that the budget of this program is not large, because it is not even EUR 143 million, but it must be remembered that this program is only to complement other EU programs, so summa summarum, I think that it will work well to achieve the goals,which we mean.One of the important principles of this program is the partnership principle.It aims to involve regional and local authorities in the implementation of the reform process, and that is, in my opinion, very important.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of this report, but I would like to mention what I said in the debate: it is very important that this support program for structural reforms for the period 2017-2020 achieves its purpose.Let's go and support local authorities, especially those in rural areas, on public-private partnerships, the money that is taken not to be taken from other structural funds, because then we move from one pocket to another.It is very important to focus this support program for the assistance of town halls, small town halls, small towns, communes, where investment is really needed, but I do not know how to use European money.And I hope that this support program for structural reforms will achieve its purpose, but with these conditions that I have said, and I believe that we, the Parliament, the specialized committees, have the task to check if this happens.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - The 2017-2020 structural reforms will have an important partner. This partner will be self-governments of two levels: the commune level and the regional level. The amounts that are allocated here are not large, but it is important that this regulation ends a certain debate about large funds dedicated to regions and local governments. I am glad that in today's vote we have accepted - in the end - this next perspective, in which local and regional self-governments will be the key and important partner. In the previous discussion, a lot of comments were made about bank financing systems, etc., because in many respects it is the market that should decide what these investments are intended for. But the local government is also a market, the local government is the entity that is most sensitive to the local community, and I am very glad that we are ending this debate with today's vote

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I welcome the fact that, in the Structural Reform Support Programme for the period 2017-2020, we included references to the core principle of cohesion policy – namely that the actions and activities under the new programme should also be able to contribute to social, economic and territorial cohesion. We also included cohesion as an area eligible for support, even though this was not originally proposed by the Commission. Finally, we struck a deal with the Council on involving regional and local players in Member States’ reform processes. We succeeded in having increased scrutiny by Parliament, enhanced transparency which will enable us to access the programme’s added value. Moreover, I welcome the focus on ensuring transparency in two stages – ex—ante and ex—post. When the disclosure of relevant information would not adversely affect the implementation of support measures, full information regarding cooperation and support plans should be provided to the Council and to Parliament.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - The new regulation approved today on the Member States' Reform Support Program will help implement measures to improve local institutions, governance, administration, economy and sectors. The specific objectives of the program are to support the initiatives of national authorities to structure reforms according to priorities, to improve their ability to develop and implement reform strategies and to follow an integrated approach to ensure coherence between objectives and means of all sectors. Actions funded by the program include seminars, workshops and conferences, working visits, studies, research, analyzes and surveys. Member States wishing to receive support under the program will have to submit a request to do so as part of the European Semester dialogue. The Commission and the Member States concerned will ensure coherence, complementarity and synergies between the actions carried out under this program and those implemented through other EU instruments.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I supported this report and I was surprised by what I heard when explaining that, in fact, this program was useless, according to one colleague. I consider this to be a very meaningless statement. Firstly, this program is intended to help Member States implement structural reforms, and there are so many areas where Europe is out of breath that deep structural reforms are needed. Secondly, this program is open to partnerships with municipalities, cities and regions, and this partnership is very important, because if the government does not meet macroeconomic conditionality under cohesion policy, then municipalities and cities, among others, are punished for it. It is important that they not only have to lose money, but also be able to take part in the implementation of structural reforms. The program is not very rich, one hundred and forty million euros is not a big amount, on the other hand, it can help where, as I said at the beginning, Europe is a little out of breath.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: - I voted in favor.I want to thank my colleague Diaconu for the work done, even if the scarcity of the funds made available makes this initiative more symbolic than anything else.However, the symbols are also important and in this regard I will work hard to ensure that the areas affected by natural disasters are not neglected in the initiatives, such as in central Italy where there is a great cultural heritage.Cultural heritage is a privilege, but it is also a source of duties.Paraphrasing a Native American saying, we inherited it from our parents and we borrow it from our children to whom we must return it.In many areas of Europe today, austerity policies and cuts have made this task very difficult.I hope that this initiative, this European Year of Cultural Heritage, will be a first step to change direction.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Madam President, I supported the proposal to create a European Year of Cultural Heritage in 2018, because it is our rich cultural heritage that is the driving force for the social and economic development of the European Union. I believe that this initiative will give a positive impetus and visibility to the sector, which has been significantly neglected due to the financial and economic crisis. The protection of cultural heritage must be on the political agenda, and not only in 2018. The cultural and creative industries create 12 million jobs, equivalent to 7.5% of the Union's workforce. Despite their enormous economic potential, only the Creative Europe Program and the European Fund for Strategic Investments have identified this sector as a priority. For this reason, I defend the position that a separate financial resource must be set aside for the implementation of the European Year of Cultural Heritage. The success of the initiative must not be at the expense of other successful cultural programs.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I would like to emphasize that it is very important that the European Parliament has today decided on the European Year of Cultural Heritage by a large majority of Members: 554 of those present.This is great support for next year, as well as support for the changes proposed by the European Parliament compared to the European Commission.We have suggested that we emphasize 2018 as a symbolic year of 100 years since the end of the First World War, and also a year in which several new states were created a hundred years ago in Europe.We also emphasized the need to learn from history so that we could make better decisions about today and the future of a common Europe.The European Parliament has also increased the budget for this year to EUR 8 million, and I consider it important that preparations can begin now for this year to be truly successful.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Madam President, it is a great pleasure that the European Union has declared 2018 the European Year of Cultural Heritage, but there is something bizarre tragicomic about the fact that, while a wagon sacrifices money for this purpose, it decides to divert a large number of migrants to the European Union.To the Union and constantly insults the few countries that resist it.There is no need to explain to anyone, it is enough to walk here one thing about how Europe’s cultural heritage is threatened by mass migration.In any case, I can promise, on behalf of the majority of the Hungarian people, that Hungary will enthusiastically support this European Year of Cultural Heritage and we will continue to protect Europe's cultural heritage by protecting our borders, our own state and the European Union's borders.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President!Perhaps never before has such a program to promote Europe's cultural heritage been more important and more necessary than it is now.We live in times when, instead of calling for and trying to stand - as Europeans - on one side, there are growing movements that want to divide and differentiate us.Therefore, I believe that the European Year of Cultural Heritage initiative is very important and should promote cultural diversity and intercultural dialogue in Europe.The aim of this program should also be to raise awareness of the history of Europe, the civilization values that Europe has given the world, so that we Europeans - as I said at the beginning - always stand on one side.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, I supported this initiative from the very beginning and I am glad that a man of culture from Romania, Mircea Diaconu, is the rapporteur and that today I voted for this report.The European Year of Cultural Heritage coincides for my country with the celebration of the centenary of independence and I am happy about this coincidence, but I hope that this year, the European Year of Culture, we will do something concrete for diversity, unity in diversity, asit is the motto of the European Union, to do something concrete for the preservation of cultural values and heritage in all countries, in all Member States, to make events that truly mark the European Year of Cultural Heritage.I believe that we do not know our cultures well enough, the Member States and our citizens, and I believe that we can take action to build bridges, because, in the end, culture and education connect people.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, I welcome 2018 as the European Year of Cultural Heritage and I agree that the main objective of the European Year is to celebrate European cultural heritage as a common resource from centuries of history, bringing together Member States and the peoples of Europe. At the same time, I consider this year to be a good opportunity to talk more about the past and the view of history of the peoples of Europe, as part of this past still tends to separate and contrast individual nations. I believe that the Member States of the European Union must strive for historic reconciliation, but this requires openness, a willingness to compromise and, above all, common goals and aspirations. At the dawn of European integration, there were such common goals among the founding member states, and one of the main challenges for the EU is to have such common goals on the horizon of Member States' thinking today, which can only be achieved through cooperation, mutual respect and co-operation.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I also supported this resolution because I believe that projects that lead to knowledge of our heritage, our European culture, what is common to European culture, but also possible differences from country to country and nation, I thinkthat it is very beneficial and important and leads to a natural upbringing and to the fact that we perceive and identify ourselves as Europeans and perceive Europe as one continent that has a common wealth, a common culture.That is why I supported this proposal, and I hope that some interesting projects will be implemented in Europe - not much, but at least some money - throughout Europe.I am glad that the next year was chosen, 2018, because Czechoslovakia was established in 1918 as an independent state, and we Czechs therefore remember the restoration of Czech, albeit Czechoslovak, statehood at the time.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - We have a huge inflation in Europe of various types of anniversaries, jubilees, years dedicated to a specific event.Virtually every weekend there is a ceremony in honor of someone, something or a specific event.If there is such a European Year of Heritage dedicated in 2018 to material and spiritual heritage, it must be remembered that 6 million euro for the whole of Europe means more than modestly.Therefore, on the occasion of this vote, I want to first of all appeal to the governments of individual countries to strengthen the European Year of Heritage with their own means, initiatives, as well as my own ideas and projects that will give a common denominator and show the roots of Europe, show our heritage, show the system of values,its changes, but also to promote European heritage beyond its borders.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I welcome the fact that we have been leading this initiative for the establishment of a European Year of Cultural Heritage in 2018, keeping pressure on the Commission until the presentation of the proposal in September 2016. It was followed by an accelerated procedure, agreed among all political groups, to be able to have the position of the Parliament as quickly as possible in order to start negotiations with the Council. An agreement was finally achieved under the Maltese Presidency. The European Year of Cultural Heritage 2018 will support cultural activities and projects in order to protect, safeguard, use, develop and promote Europeans’ shared cultural heritage. Parliament has secured an EUR 8 million budget for these activities and managed to ensure Parliament’s active involvement in the management of the Year. Our aim is to involve citizens in the recognition and promotion of their cultural heritage.  Și aș vrea să fac o referire la faptul că a fost aici o colegă care mereu folosește greșit în limba română termenul „președintă”. În limba română, președintă este defectiv de gen, există numai președinte.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, I voted against the report on the European Year of Cultural Heritage as a sign of protest, because the report says nothing about the return of stolen archaeological treasures to their place of origin, as stipulated in Directive 93/7 EEC but also as stipulated in the Convention of UNESCO of 1970. Madam President, 76 years have passed since, on April 27, 1941, the Nazi occupation troops entered Greece, entered Athens. During the Nazi occupation, archaeological treasures were stolen, which are included in the special volume published in 1946 by the Greek Ministry of Education and in the special report of the British Ministry of War. We demand the immediate return of the archaeological treasures stolen by the Nazis during the years 1941-1944.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - The designation of 2018 as the European Year of Cultural Heritage represents a precious opportunity to promote our cultural excellence as a shared resource, the result of a centuries-old history. In an era characterized by growing cultural diversity, cultural heritage can play an important role in the cohesion of the community. From archaeological sites to architecture, from medieval castles to popular traditions, to the arts, Europe's cultural heritage is the beating heart of the identity and collective memory of European citizens and as such must be safeguarded and protected. Not to mention that around 300 000 people are directly employed in the cultural heritage sector in the European Union, which indirectly generates 7.8 million jobs. On my territory I live the virtuous example of the Bourbon Royal Palace of Caserta and Pompeii, now they fly for the tourist economy of an entire region. We need to get busy, 2018 is around the corner. Everyone must do their part so that the European Year of Cultural Heritage is transformed into a concrete opportunity to relaunch the image of the Old Continent in the eyes of the world.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I supported this report and I am very pleased that 2018 was chosen as the European Year of Cultural Heritage.In doing so, we are showing the direction of our priorities, we are showing that culture is indeed a value that is very crucial, especially in these years, and I think for the future of Europe as such, because culture defines us as we are and reflects our surroundings.I want to support the fact that the budget has increased, albeit a little, but at the same time I want to appreciate the fact that 2018 coincides with the year of the celebration of Czech and Czechoslovak statehood, because in 2018 the Czech Republic (respectively Czechoslovakia) will remember one hundred years since independence.I think it will be a great challenge for the government of the Czech Republic to find sufficient links to events related to Europe's cultural heritage.So far, I feel like this isn't happening very well.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! The announcement of the European Year of Cultural Heritage is a very good occasion to remind you that Europe existed hundreds of years before the European Union was founded. Europe emerged after the fall of the Roman Empire, when, during the Dark Ages, St. Benedict brightened its space with his monasteries. And it is about this Europe of St. John Paul II said in Gniezno at the congress of presidents of Central Europe that this river contains many tributaries, but that its mainstream is Christianity. There is one more reason to remind you of the need to remember our heritage. We see very little of it in our European Parliament building, in both of our buildings. Here we see neither Charlemagne, nor the Holy Queen Jadwiga, nor the general councils, nor the Battle of Warsaw, when our grandparents saved the world from Bolshevism. It is time to remember that Europe is the reality we are to serve, we did not create it, we can only protect it.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfábhar na tuarascála seo agus dar ndóigh tá sé tábhachtach go gcuirimid béim ar ár gcultúr oidhreachta agus aontaím go mór leis an moladh atá ann go mbeadh an bhliain seo chugainn ina Bliain Chultúir Oidhreachta na hEorpa. Thabharfadh sin seans dúinn aird agus aitheantas a thabhairt dár n-oidhreacht agus, go háirithe, an pháirt a ghlacann cultúr i saibhreas ár saol i gcoitinne agus i bhfás gheilleagar na hEorpa. Freisin, ba mhaith liom nach ndéanfaimid dearmad ar scéalaíocht mar chuid den oidhreacht sin. Nílim ag caint faoi scéalta a dhéanann daoine suas, ach scéalaíocht a insíonn dúinn faoinár n-oidhreacht agus go háirithe ár n-oidhreacht Chríostúil atá an-saibhir san Eoraip agus a nascann sinn le chéile. Agus mar fhocal scoir, ná déan dearmad ar spórt mar chuid dár gcultúr oidhreachta chomh maith.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President! I will always defend those budget lines that are dedicated to young people, whether it be for education, creative markets or scholarship programs such as "Erasmus +". It is important, however, that these funds dedicated to the youngest, the youngest on the market, the youngest acquiring education, are spent not only rationally, but in accordance with their interests. I have appealed many times for, above all, the elimination of arrears - the arrears due and those arrears that appeared as a result of various barriers, including bureaucratic ones. I am pleased that this report, which ends 2015, shows a reduction in the outstanding liabilities dedicated specifically to young people, be it the "Europe for Citizens" program, "Creative Europe" or programs such as "Erasmus +". I hope that a similar report will be produced in 2016.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, I voted against the discharge report for the general budget of the European Union, in particular for the European Commission, because I believe that the action of the European Commission is one of opacity and mismanagement. At the same time, I would like to raise a broader issue and protest, because today we voted on fifty-two discharge reports from the institutions of the European Union, and all that is a serious process, the debate, the scrutiny, took place yesterday in a debate of a few hours. It is impossible - I am sure - to have serious control over the operation of the financial institutions of all organizations and to be able to give an exemption. I voted against, I did not give a discharge to any of the organizations, among other things because there is no serious discussion, no control was done, and we saw here voting one report after another in a process which I think is a shame for democratic control to be exercised by the European Parliament.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Madam President, the work of the European Court of Auditors has been under expectations for many years. Of course, it depends on everyone's expectations. For example, the European Court of Auditors did not deal with the financial transparency of the European institutions, did not look deeply at the way management is done in all European institutions, also, conflicts of interest seemed to no longer exist for the Court of Auditors, the policy human resources, how to hire, promote. And, as I mentioned conflicts of interest, I am very concerned that since 2012 the European Court of Auditors has not made any special reports on conflicts of interest, especially for agencies working with industries, and it is vital for health and our lives to do this and it's about agencies in the food industry, agencies in the pharmaceutical industry, the chemical industry, the aircraft construction industry. All this is essential, because when there is a conflict of interest between European officials and industry, we all suffer. I would also like to say just one thing: in 2015, the Court, although it promised to reduce staff by 5%, made new hires.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Madam President, in the case of this agency, as in the European Court of Auditors, I voted against the discharge because I personally found irregularities. At ACER, the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators, many malfunctions and irregularities were registered and, then, as I said, I did not vote for the discharge. There are serious problems in human resources policy, employment policy, for example, in 2015, the Agency hired an 8th grade assistant, although it was only allowed to hire one for grade 5. That means more money, where did it get them? and why doesn't the Court of Auditors sanction it? Or, an employee who won a lawsuit against the Agency was no longer employed, even though the Agency was required to hire him. Also in 2014, the head of the administrative service was reclassified with a very high rank, being in a conflict of interest because he was a member of the committee that decided to make these promotions. Therefore, I did not vote in favor of ... (the President cut off the speaker).

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Madam President, this European Banking Authority claims to be responsible for consumer protection in relation to banks and customers. I’m not a financial professional, but as a lawyer, I don’t value their work much when I see that somehow this terrible, fraud-based so-called foreign currency loan scheme, among others in Hungary. I see that even today, people are being evicted day by day under brutal conditions, and tens of thousands of families are terrified of the horror of eviction. Please, where is this European Banking Authority or Banking Authority? These people are still consumers, still customers of banks, or former customers, come forward and help these people, protect their rights! And where the European Banking Authority is then, Mrs President, are well aware of these photographs, which I hand over to people rushing down at Ferihegy Airport, in a vulnerable situation, in a hurry, looking for their flight, with three banks represented there and signed recklessly. , recklessly engaging people. I would also ask Mr President personally to act on this matter.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Madam President, this time I want to motivate why I voted in favor of the European Medicines Agency discharge and I will start from what many people say, that the pharmaceutical industry leads our world. But we must not be intimidated by this, we must make the right policies and the right laws for the citizens. The losses due to counterfeit medicines in the European Union amount to 10.2 billion per year. It's a huge amount. And, most importantly, we have counterfeit drugs that make people sick, not make them healthy. Since 2013, the Agency has received about 40 complaints in this regard and I think it would have received more if it could have a system to protect those who report. I am glad that the Agency has now adopted such a regulation this year which helps it to verify allegations of non-compliance with medicines and while protecting whistleblowers.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, I voted against the 2015 discharge of the European Union Network and Information Security Agency ENISA and I explain why. The organization was founded and settled in Heraklion, Crete, but from the first moment its leadership wanted to leave Heraklion, Crete and methodized in various ways, so it essentially split the organization into two parts: one administrative and one technological, and the technological department transferred it to Athens. The administrative department remained in Heraklion, in an area of ​​4.5 thousand square meters, where it is located and hosted without any costs. Costs have been incurred from the decision to move ENISA or part of it to Athens, which incurs costs for administration and buildings. I protest against this unacceptable situation! I am not going to dismiss this organization and I believe that the leadership activity of this organization should be controlled immediately.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, we voted today on fifty-two discharge for the institutions and agencies of the European Union.I would like to comment on two.The first is Eurofound, an agency with which I have specific experience in using its studies and publications in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.In 2015, the agency managed EUR 20.86 billion.I believe that these funds are being used effectively.As part of the amendment of the legislative basis for Eurofound, we will try to make this activity even more efficient.I think that the discharge was justified.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, this is therefore a discharge for Frontex, whose appropriations were increased by 46% in 2015.I believe that, given the European Union's priorities, which is the protection of the external borders, this increase was perfectly appropriate.Thanks to the increased resources, the agency was able to save hundreds of thousands of lives, we even mention the number of 250,000 people at sea.However, for further and most effective action, it is necessary to divide and define the responsibilities between Frontex and the Internal Security Fund in order to avoid unnecessary duplication of effort and thus waste of resources.It is good that this agency has received a report from the Court of Auditors stating that the funds have been reimbursed in accordance with the objectives set.

name: Ulrike RODUST
text: - Madam President! There was one amendment to my report - I rejected that amendment. I explained my reasons for this in plenary yesterday. In summary, I believe that this amendment is inconsistent with the current common fisheries policy. However, since there are helpful things in the report, I abstained from voting on the resolution instead of voting against it. I could not vote in favor of the report in this case because in my original draft report I made a dichotomy: what is possible under the current CFP and what should be taken into account in a potential future CFP? This dichotomy was voted away in the Fisheries Committee. This means that public funding should now be guaranteed under the current CFP. In my opinion, funding based on Article 349 of the employment contract undermines the coherence of this common policy.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - The outermost regions have historically been disadvantaged, not only by their geographical condition but also by short-sighted political choices conditioned by the interests of the Old Continent. That is why I welcome the Rodust report because it protects small-scale fishing and the protection of fishermen. In the outermost regions, small fishing vessels represent the vast majority of registered vessels and are often the only ones to defend their seas from illegal fishing by large non-EU fleets. The fishing that defends itself here is sustainable fishing, the one mentioned in the latest reform of the common policy and which is in no way threatened by these boats, which among other things hold only a minimal percentage of the fishing quotas in their seas. Mutatis mutandis the same fishery that we will have to defend in our seas is unfortunately threatened by large fishing boats from Northern Europe and beyond. It is fishing carried out by small fishermen, too often with improvised boats and for this reason also not very sustainable and safe. So let's use what we have, let's use the structural funds, let's use the EMFF to support our fishermen. The common fisheries policy is not perfect, especially for our Mediterranean, but for this very reason we will have to do everything to support local fishing, in full compliance with the limits imposed by law and by environmental sustainability.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - I think that sustainable fishing, which uses traditional gear, is the basis for successful coastal communities, and it also contributes to food security in the outermost regions. It is therefore important that the food security objectives of the local population are included in local fisheries, as, unfortunately, food security in the outermost regions is too dependent on imports today. In addition, there are diverse small communities in the outermost regions, which rely heavily on traditional coastal and small-scale fishing and for which fishing is often the only way to earn a living. I think that special attention needs to be paid to the protection of marine biological resources around the outermost regions, and that special attention must, of course, also be paid to fishing. Therefore, fishing in the waters of the outermost regions should only be allowed for fishing vessels registered in the ports of those regions, and here, of course, the European Commission must take its own step and take some responsibility for the outermost regions in the maritime field.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of this report because I believe that sustainable fishing, using traditional gear, forms the basis for the prosperity of coastal communities and contributes to food security in the outermost regions. The outermost regions are in a unique situation within the European Union. In a natural context marked by insularity, tropical climate and a rugged and volcanic relief, these regions are very far from the European continent, as is the case in my country, the Azores and Madeira. But they have a historical relevance, they play a strategic role in protecting Europe's sea routes and defending its external borders. In recent years fishing pressure has increased in the exclusive economic zone of some ORs, between 100 and 200 miles, with fishing predominantly carried out by fleets not belonging to the respective ORs. The European Union, geographically projected over four seas and two oceans and surrounded by islands, must protect its marine biological resources and create measures to support its artisanal and traditional fishing vessels, on which the survival of many fishing communities in the ORs depends. We cannot deceive ourselves, what is at stake here is the defense of the survival of the fishing sector in the ORs.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - The fact is that the textile and clothing sector employs as many as 60 million people worldwide and creates many jobs, especially in developing countries. However, it should be noted that this sector poses the highest risk of human rights violations as well as employment rights, so many workers in the clothing sector do not earn a decent wage, even large enough to survive. And most violations of both labor and human rights in the sector are related to various aspects, including the rights of workers who are denied the right to trade unions, in fact those fundamental rights that apply in the workplace and those fundamental labor rights, including theft wages, forced labor, low wages, arbitrary redundancies, dangerous jobs, unhealthy working conditions. And here, of course, the European Union must also take its share of responsibility in terms of legislative proposals that will make such relations impossible.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of this report because I remember well that in 2013 a three-story building collapsed in which a fabric factory in Bangladesh worked, revealing non-compliance with basic safety standards and the dark side of the international clothing industry. 377 people died in this tragedy. The harsh reality is that, today, the labor force of the garment industry worldwide is mostly female. About 85% of workers in the sector are women who often face difficult and very poorly paid working conditions and where child labor is a sad reality. For all these reasons, I consider it very important that the Commission proposes binding legislation in the clothing sector, in order to ensure that the European Union and its trading partners and operators fulfill their obligation: respect human rights and the highest social and environmental standards . This report demonstrates that Europe recognizes the need for a level playing field to protect workers from environmental and social dumping.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President!We are talking about a very important industry sector, because it employs tens of millions of people around the world, and especially women who, in the market, especially in poor, developing countries, have a very big problem with getting a job.This industry is affected by various pathologies regarding violations of human rights, labor rights, environmental protection, health and safety, etc.That is why it is important that the European Union, as a leader in the fight for civilization values, introduces them in those countries.However, we must remember that these processes must be evolutionary and not revolutionary, because if we wanted to require immediate standards from these countries, such as those in force in Europe, we could be counterproductive.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Madam President, statistics show that in the European Union, only 3% of farmers control 52.5% of agricultural land. In Bulgaria, the statistics are even more worrying - only 1.5% of all registered farms cultivate 82% of the land in the country. The main financial resources are concentrated in these farms. European subsidies must reach a larger number of beneficiaries in order to achieve balanced and equitable growth in the Union. Land can be property, but it is also a public good from which social obligations arise. I strongly believe that land - state or municipal property - should not be sold. Instead, they should only be rented out: rented out to start-up farmers, young farmers or rented out to small farms. By preserving the lands, it is possible to go in the right direction if necessary.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Madam President, I was very pleased to vote in favor of this report on land grabbing.It clearly has two forms.One, I think my Bulgarian fellow Member, can support this is the abduction by foreigners.The solution here, as I said in the debate, would be to remove arable land from the chapter on the free movement of capital, as it is not speculative capital but a source of livelihood for local farmers.The other form of land grabbing is the fraudulent acquisition of land by local oligarchs through fraudulent tenders.And here there is a double obligation.One is the action of the judiciary, the local judiciary, so the prosecution should be hired in this regard.The other is that this is an area where the European Union should also act, as these people receive huge subsidies per hectare, European Union public money.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, in the end I did not support this report, I abstained, even though there are some good passages regarding support for small and medium-sized farmers in rural areas. I really do not think that the role of the European Union is to interfere in the ownership structure of land in rural areas. This is really something that can be very dangerous. I would not like to see that here we call for someone to be expropriated and for someone's property to be restricted by law. I think that we should respect the right to property as a fundamental right of a democratic state governed by the rule of law, and we should, if necessary, leave it to the Member States to restrict the management of agricultural land in certain cases. I am not a supporter of this, and even if I do not like the fact that property is concentrated in the hands of only a certain percentage of farmers, I will always respect property, defend it and respect it. So be careful not to get somewhere where we are at odds with the rule of law.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - Any country in difficulty or economic crisis needs help, assistance and support, and of course Venezuela.Of course, we must use democratic standards, democratic procedures and, of course, be aware that each country, of course, decides within itself, in essence, about its future.And the most democratic way of expressing, of course, respecting the will of the people is through elections.And nothing is different in Venezuela either.In any case, all violence must be strongly condemned, and of course the violation of freedoms and human rights, restrictions on rights, freedom of expression and media freedom, and of course all those violations that intentionally or unintentionally overthrow the government in a democratic way, ie violence.but not with the elections themselves.However, I think that the European Union must also take its step here, which is why I also stayed with this report.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). - Madam President, what is happening in Venezuela today is deeply worrying for everyone here in Europe and we have dead people every day. More than 26 dead in the last month, 437 injured, 1289 arrested. Fourteen journalists have been arrested and 106 have been attacked in the last four weeks. Prisons are full of opposition figures, we have more than 100 political prisoners and this list includes all the leaders of the opposition. Today, Madam President, in the European Parliament we have condemned the continuing unconstitutional overthrow of the democratic order in Venezuela, called on the Venezuelan Government and the Supreme Court to respect the Constitution, and called for, among other things, the preservation of discrimination and independence political prisoners. These are obvious things. Unfortunately not for the group of the European Left, which has decided not to endorse our resolution and the question is simple: Can European governments have common values ​​and common goals with the Venezuelan government, maintain selective kinships? Our answer today is that this is contrary to the basic principles that unite us.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: - Madam president. Venezuela, gentlemen, is today a tyranny. There is no food, no medicine, but the Government liquidates the last gold reserves, ready to arm half a million militiamen. In true narco style, the Chavista regime is executing its own citizens. And yet Venezuelans do not give up. Unarmed women do not give up by pushing back armored cars. Students do not give up attending to their fellow gunmen. Maduro, isolated and designated as a criminal dictator, isolates Venezuela by removing it from the Organization of American States. Maduro belongs to the club of Pinochet, Videla, Fujimori. Videla threw opponents into the sea. Maduro shoots them in the head. Europe, the whole world, we all have to take sides, because democracy is the only hope left for Venezuela. Restore constitutional order, release political prisoners, and call elections. This is the party that Europe takes. Lords of Podemos and Izquierda Unida: either you are with the unarmed woman who stops the armored vehicle or you are with the one who gives the order to shoot. You choose.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I supported this resolution, which clearly criticizes the current political situation in Venezuela. I am convinced that Europe, resp. The European Union should not only deal with the internal market, with its own problems, but also with the guardian of human rights, freedom and democracy in other countries on our planet. That is why it is good that we are dealing with the situation in Venezuela and that we are adopting this harsh resolution, which criticizes the current president, who has made a coup through the Supreme Court against parliament and does not respect the majority in parliament, which is in opposition to President Maduro. Although, unfortunately, our resolution is likely to be declaratory and will not change the situation in Venezuela much, I think it is very good - and this resolution makes it clear - to support democratic forces in Venezuela, to support the opposition against President Maduro and to do everything possible. that this tyrant be overthrown and replaced at least a little by a democratic government.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of the resolution on Venezuela because I understand that given the increase in the intensity of the clashes in that country, and the brutal repression of the regime that has already caused more than 20 deaths in a month, this is a form of this condemn this violence and support the Venezuelan people and the Portuguese who live there in their legitimate aspirations for a regime change, which will allow them to face the serious humanitarian crisis created by Maduro, to disarm armed groups, to release political prisoners, to restore judicial independence and the powers of the National Assembly and, with the establishment of a transitional government of national salvation, to finally call free, general and democratic elections, duly supervised by independent observers. Just today, a kind of Venexit was communicated following Maduro's announcement to withdraw Venezuela from the Organization of American States, thus isolating itself even more from the international community. We cannot be accomplices for the silence or for the euphemisms of a totalitarian regime that violates human rights with impunity and leads its own people to a situation of misery and social and political conflict. Venezuelans, who have so generously welcomed thousands and thousands of European emigrants for decades, now need our support and solidarity more than ever.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.
